questions.text: Fingerprints are discovered by
questions.solution:
• Fingerprints are discovered by Sir William J Herschel in 1877.
  • It is systematized by Sir Francis Galton in1892.
  • It is further improved by Sir Edward Henry.

FRANCIS GALTON - His study of minutiae in prints provided the foundation for meaningful comparison of different prints, and he was able to construct a statistical proof of the uniqueness, by minutiae, of individual prints. Galton also provided the first workable fingerprint classification system, which was later adapted by E. R.

EDWARD HENRY - Sir Edward Richard Henry, 1st Baronet, GCVO, KCB, CSI, KPM was the Commissioner of Police of the Metropolis from 1903 to 1918. His commission saw the introduction of police dogs to the force, but he is best remembered today for his championship of the method of fingerprinting to identify criminals.

EDMUND LOCARD - Dr. Edmond Locard was a French criminologist, the pioneer in forensic science who became known as the "Sherlock Holmes of France". He formulated the basic principle of forensic science: "Every contact leaves a trace". This became known as Locard's exchange principle.

questions.text: A forensic expert is examining the pelvic bone and lower vertebrae of an unknown individual, to determine the sex. Which of the following is regarded as the best source of information for the same?
questions.solution:
• The pubis of the pelvic bone has long been regarded as the best sources of information for determining the sex of an unknown individual.
  • The femur is the most useful long bone for sex determination, due to its length and massiveness.
  • Sacrum is least reliable bone for sex determination.

Subpubic concavity is also a good indicator of sex. The subpubic region is located on the pubis, inferiorly to the obturator foramen. In females, the subpubic region is concave, while in males the subpubic region is either straight or convex.

questions.text: What is the cause of death in smoke inhalation?
questions.solution:
• Victims of smoke inhalation are affected by carbon monoxide poisoning. In carbon monoxide poisoning, the cause of death is anaemic hypoxia
  • Carbon monoxide has a higher affinity to haemoglobin compared to oxygen and hence the amount of haemoglobin available for oxygen transport is markedly reduced.
  • It displaces oxygen from its combination with haemoglobin and forms a relatively stable compound known as carboxyhemoglobin. It thus reduces the oxygen content of the blood, and hence, that of the tissues. It acts as a chemical asphyxiant and produces death due to anaemic anoxia.

questions.text: Which of the following sites is more prone to bruising with blunt trauma?
questions.solution:
The shins are particularly prone to bruising with blunt trauma.

Resilient areas, such as the abdominal wall and buttocks, bruise less with a given impact than a region where underlying bone acts as an anvil with the skin between the bone and the inflicting force. The head, chest, and shins are the examples.

A direct trauma to the shin bone can damage the periosteum (known as bone bruising of the tibia or periosteal contusion). This causes a collection of blood underneath the periosteum of the shin bone.

questions.text: The body of a hiker is found naked on a snow trail. It is hypothesised that he actively undressed just minutes prior to his death. Which of the following statements regarding this phenomenon is true?
questions.solution:
The given phenomenon of paradoxical undressing is likely due to peripheral vasodilation.

Reciprocal or paradoxical undressing:

  • This is a strange condition seen in accidental hypothermia, particularly in old persons.
  • In this person take off some or all of their clothing.
  • The cause of the condition is not known.
  • It may be due to long exposure to severe cold producing paralysis of the thermal regulatory mechanism (once the body temperature has fallen below about 30°C).
  • This results in failure of vasoconstriction of arterioles of the skin which results in a flow of blood from the core of the body (Reflex vasodilation), thus giving an exaggerated sensation of warmth.
  • Terminal hallucinations occur.
  • Because of the great discomfort (as he feels hot), the person may undress himself.
  • In such case, there may be suspicion of sexual offence.

Other associated features include:

  • Bruises and scratches of the knees, shanks, and upper limbs caused by late-phase attempts at crawling.
  • The hide-and-die phenomenon in some cases.

Paradoxical undressing is a phenomenon characterizing some fatal hypothermia cases. The victims, despite low environmental temperatures, paradoxically remove their clothes due to a sudden feeling of warmth.

questions.text: A pedestrian hit by a car hurls up on the windshield following which his head strikes the road. How is the head injury described?
questions.solution:
In this case, pedestrian hit by a car (Primary impact injury) hurls up on the windshield (Secondary impact injury) following which his head strikes the road (Secondary injury.

Injuries to pedestrians:

  • Secondary impact injuries are the injuries sustained by a pedestrian by falling over the vehicle.
  • Secondary injuries (Sometimes also called as Tertiary injuries) are the injuries sustained by a pedestrian by falling over the ground after being hit by the vehicle.

questions.text: In the case of rape of a young child, the hymen is usually:
questions.solution:
In the case of a young child, the hymen is deeply situated and usually intact after intercourse.

  • In young children there are few or no signs of general violence, for the child usually has no idea of what is happening, and also incapable of resisting.
  • In an older child, typical grasping injuries and bruises from blows may be found.

questions.text: Cyanide antidote kit does not contain:
questions.solution:
The 3-step cyanide antidote kit is used for cyanide poisoning.

The kit contains:

  • 12 amyl nitrite pearls,
  • Two 10 ml vials of 3% sodium nitrite
  • Two 50 ml vials of sodium thiosulfate
  1. 0.3 ml ampoule (perles) of amyl nitrite is broken in a gauze and the victim is made to inhale for 30 seconds, every minute (1 step), and use a new pearls every 3 min. Stop amyl nitrite if systolic BP is < 80 mmHg.
  2. 10 ml of 3% solution (300 mg) of sodium nitrite is injected IV slowly over 5 min (2 step), followed by 50 ml of 25% solution (12.5g0 of sodium thiosulfate over 10-20 min. by the same needle (3 step).

The mechanism of action of amyl nitrite and sodium nitrite as antidotes for cyanide poisoning is to produce methemoglobinemia and vasodilation.

Intravenous sodium nitrite produces significant methemoglobinemia.

Methaemoglobin has a higher affinity for cyanide than cytochrome oxidase complex and removes cyanide from the cytochrome oxidase.

Cyanides combine with methaemoglobin and form non-toxic cyanmethemoglobin which in presence of rhodanese and sulphate donors, such as thiosulphate, converts cyanide to thiocyanate which is excreted in the urine.

questions.text: Black foot disease is caused by:
questions.solution:
Black foot disease is caused by chronic poisoning by Arsenic

Blackfoot disease is a characteristic vascular disease associated with long-term exposure to inorganic arsenic. It occurred in areas of Taiwan with elevated arsenic in drinking water. The patients suffer severe systemic arteriosclerosis with black, mummified dry foot-gangrene in severe cases.

Signs & symptoms of Chronic Arsenic Poisoning:

  • Earliest sign is emaciation.
  • Catarrhal changes - Rhinitis, lacrimation, conjunctivitis, bronchial catarrh
  • Hyperpigmentation of palms and soles is seen. It mimics Addison's disease.
  • Hyperkeratosis of palm and soles.
  • Rashes resembling fading measles
  • Rain drop brown pigmentation
  • Black foot disease is caused. It is a gangrenous change.
  • Aldrich-Mee's lines (leukonychia) are seen (Multiple, transverse parallel white lines in the nails. Takes about 30 days after first exposure. Also seen in thallium poisoning).
  • Cancer (A precancerous lesion called Bowen's disease, Basal cell carcinoma, Small cell carcinoma, Ca lung and Ca bladder)

questions.text: A person fabricates a contusion with marking nut juice with an intension of false allegation on one of his enemies. He is punishable under BNS section.
questions.solution:
Fabricating false evidence is punishable under Sec. 229 BNS.

Important BNS sections related to false evidence and false certificates.

227 → Giving false evidence (Perjury) - Definition

228 → Fabricating false evidence - Definition

229 → Punishment for Sec. 227 and 228 BNS (Up to 7 years of imprisonment)

234 → Issuing or signing false certificate - Punishment is same as for giving false evidence

  • Sec. 227 BNS - Giving false evidence (PERJURY):Whoever, being legally bound by an oath or by an express provision of law to state the truth, or being bound by law to make a declaration upon any subject, makes any statement which is false, and which he either knows or believes to be false or does not believe to be true, is said to give false evidence.
  • Sec. 228 BNS - Fabricating false evidence:Whoever causes any circumstance to exist or makes any false entry in any book or record, or electronic record or makes any document or electronic record containing a false statement, intending that such circumstance, false entry or false statement may appear in evidence in a judicial proceeding, or in a proceeding taken by law before a public servant as such, or before an arbitrator, and that such circumstance, false entry or false statement, so appearing in evidence, may cause any person who in such proceeding is to form an opinion upon the evidence, to entertain an erroneous opinion touching any point material to the result of such proceeding is said "to fabricate false evidence".
  • Sec. 229 BNS - Punishment for false evidence:(1) Whoever intentionally gives false evidence in any stage of a judicial proceeding, or fabricates false evidence for the purpose of being used in any stage of a judicial proceeding, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend toseven years,and shall also be liable to fine which may extend to ten thousand rupees. (2) Whoever intentionally gives or fabricates false evidence in any case other than that referred to in sub-section (1), shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, and shall also be liable to fine which may extend to five thousand rupees.
  • Sec. 234 BNS - Issuing or signing false certificate:Whoever issues or signs any certificate required by law to be given or signed, or relating to any fact of which such certificate is by law admissible in evidence, knowing or believing that such certificate is false in any material point, shall be punished in the same manner as if he gave false evidence.

questions.text: A dead body with an alleged history of suicide by hanging has come to mortuary for autopsy. On external examination, there was a ligature mark covering about one-third of the circumference of neck, salivary stain, dilated pupils and opened right eye and closed left eye. The reason for opened right eye is
questions.solution:
The phenomenon of the right eye remaining open in a hanging case is due to the compression of the cervical sympathetic chain on the right side of the neck. The cervical sympathetic chain controls autonomic functions in the head and neck, including the eyelid (via the levator palpebrae superioris muscle) and pupil (via the dilator pupillae muscle).

Mechanism:

Compression of the cervical sympathetic chain by the ligature disrupts sympathetic nerve activity on the affected side (in this case, the right side).

This leads to a loss of sympathetic input, resulting in:

Ptosis (drooping of the eyelid) or incomplete eyelid closure on the affected side.

The right eye remains open because the sympathetic control of eyelid closure is impaired.

Additionally, compression can also affect pupillary response, leading to pupil dilation (mydriasis) on the opposite side or sometimes on the same side, depending on the pressure distribution.

This autonomic dysfunction contributes to the asymmetry of eyelid appearance, such as one eye being open while the other remains closed, a common finding in cases of hanging.

Rule Out:

(a) Compression of carotid artery:

Compression of the carotid artery would result in compromised blood flow to the brain, leading to hypoxia and loss of consciousness. While this is critical in the mechanism of death by hanging, it does not explain why the right eye remains open.

(b) Compression of internal jugular vein:

Compression of the jugular vein impedes venous return from the brain, causing congestion and cyanosis of the face. However, this does not directly affect the sympathetic nerve supply to the eyelids and, therefore, is unrelated to the phenomenon of one eye remaining open.

(d) Compression of vagus nerve:

The vagus nerve is primarily involved in parasympathetic functions, including heart rate regulation and control of visceral functions. While vagus nerve compression can lead to cardiac arrest in cases of hanging, it does not influence the eyelid's ability to open or close.

Key Takeaways:

Compression of the cervical sympathetic chain in hanging cases causes autonomic dysfunction, including:

Ptosis or incomplete eyelid closure.

Pupil dilation on the same or opposite side, depending on the knot's position.

The asymmetrical appearance of the eyes (e.g., one open and one closed) is a forensic clue to the direction and impact of the ligature knot.

Structures compressed in hanging (arteries, veins, nerves) result in distinct clinical and forensic findings. However, eyelid asymmetry is specifically linked to cervical sympathetic chain compression.

Forensic examination of such findings is crucial for confirming the mechanism of hanging and differentiating it from other causes of death.

questions.text: A dead body is brought to the mortuary. On external examination, rectal temperature was found to be 39 degree Celsius. The probable cause could be
questions.solution:
A rectal temperature of 39°C (102.2°F) in a dead body suggests that the person likely died in a state of fever, which is characteristic of septicemia (a severe bacterial infection that leads to systemic inflammation and high fever).

Septicemia can cause a sustained high body temperature, and if the body is brought to the Mortuary soon after death, the temperature may still be elevated due to the body's inability to cool down quickly.

The temperature of the body post-mortem (called post-mortem temperature) can provide clues regarding the cause of death, and in the case of septicemia, it may be elevated for a period before the body cools.

Rule Out:

  • a) Intra-abdominal hemorrhage: While it can lead to death, it usually causes a rapid decline in body temperature, rather than sustained fever.
  • c) Corrosive poisoning: This can cause death due to organ damage, but fever is not a typical postmortem finding in corrosive poisoning cases.
  • d) Cyanide poisoning: Cyanide typically causes death by hypoxia and may not result in a high body temperature. It usually causes rapid collapse and coma without a prolonged fever.

Key Takeaways:

  • An elevated post-mortem body temperature (39°C) is often associated with septicemia, as it can cause sustained fever before death.
  • Septicemia leads to systemic infection and inflammation, which can elevate body temperature until the body cools after death.

questions.text: Identify the range
questions.solution:
The image shows characteristic tattooing or stippling, which is caused by unburnt or partially burnt gunpowder particles impacting the skin. This pattern is typically seen when a pistol is fired from an intermediate range, usually between 1 to 3 feet (30-90 cm).

Key features of pistol intermediate-range wounds:

  • Tattooing (stippling): Fine black or brown marks caused by gunpowder particles embedding into the skin.
  • No soot deposition, burning, or muzzle imprint, which are hallmarks of closer ranges.
  • A clean, well-defined entry wound may also be visible depending on the angle.

Rule Out:

  • b) Rifle close range: Rifle wounds at close range are associated with greater tissue destruction and potentially soot or burning, none of which are evident here.
  • c) Pistol close range: Close-range pistol wounds (<1 foot) show soot deposition, burning, and possibly a muzzle imprint, absent in the given image.
  • d) Shotgun intermediate: Shotgun intermediate wounds show pellet dispersion and irregular, scalloped edges due to multiple projectiles, not seen here.

Key Takeaways:

  1. Intermediate pistol range shows tattooing (stippling) due to gunpowder particles.
  2. Soot deposition or burning indicates close-range firing (<1 foot).
  3. Differentiation of firearm range injuries is crucial for forensic investigations.

questions.text: Treatment of choice for acute arsenic poisoning is
questions.solution:
The treatment of choice for acute arsenic poisoning is Dimercaprol (also known as British Anti-Lewisite or BAL). Dimercaprol is a chelating agent that binds to arsenic and facilitates its excretion from the body, reducing toxicity. It works by forming a stable complex with arsenic, which is then eliminated primarily through the urine. Dimercaprol is most effective when administered early after exposure and is typically used in the management of heavy metal poisonings like arsenic.

Dimercaprol is often used in combination with other chelating agents, depending on the severity and the type of poisoning.

Rule Out:

  • Penicillamine:
    • This is a chelating agent used for conditions like Wilson's disease (copper poisoning) and lead poisoning. While effective for other heavy metals, it is not the first choice for arsenic poisoning.
  • Deferoxamine:
    • Deferoxamine is primarily used to treat iron poisoning, not arsenic poisoning. It works by chelating iron, allowing its excretion, but does not effectively treat arsenic toxicity.
  • Ca EDTA:
    • Calcium EDTA is a chelating agent used for lead poisoning and is less effective in treating arsenic poisoning. It can be used in some cases of heavy metal toxicity, but it is not the first-line treatment for arsenic.

Key Takeaways:

  • Dimercaprol is the treatment of choice for acute arsenic poisoning, as it effectively chelates and removes arsenic from the body.
  • Penicillamine, Deferoxamine, and Ca EDTA are used for other types of heavy metal poisoning but are not the most effective treatments for arsenic.
  • Early administration of a chelating agent is crucial in minimizing the effects of arsenic poisoning and ensuring proper recovery.

questions.text: During hysterectomy surgery, there was a damage to the ureter. This is covered under which doctrine?
questions.solution:
The doctrine of Res ipsa loquitur, meaning "the thing speaks for itself," is applied in cases where negligence is inferred from the very nature of the incident, without needing direct evidence. In medical practice, this doctrine comes into play when the harm caused is of such a nature that it would not ordinarily occur without negligence, and the injury is under the control of the medical professional.

In the case of a hysterectomy surgery resulting in ureter damage, the injury is not a typical or expected outcome of the procedure under proper care. If the surgeon damages the ureter, the burden of proof shifts to the medical professional to demonstrate that the harm was not due to negligence. Since this injury falls outside the normal risks of surgery and often indicates a lapse in technique, it is covered under the doctrine of Res ipsa loquitur.

The patient does not need to provide direct evidence of negligence. Instead, the fact that such an injury occurred under the exclusive control of the surgeon raises a presumption of negligence unless the surgeon can provide an adequate Explanation.

Rule Out:

(a) Medical maloccurrence:

This term refers to adverse outcomes that are not preventable despite following appropriate standards of care. Ureter damage during hysterectomy is not typically classified as a "maloccurrence," as it usually suggests a preventable error rather than an unavoidable complication.

(b) Novus actus interveniens:

This legal doctrine refers to an "intervening act" that breaks the chain of causation between an initial act and the harm caused. It is not applicable here, as the injury occurred directly during surgery and was under the control of the surgeon.

(c) Therapeutic misadventure:

This term is used for unintended but recognized complications or adverse outcomes that occur despite proper care and skill during medical treatment. While this could apply to certain adverse events, ureter damage during hysterectomy is often seen as an avoidable error, making Res ipsa loquitur more appropriate in legal terms.

Key Takeaways:

The doctrine of Res ipsa loquitur applies when an injury occurs in circumstances where negligence is the most likely Explanation, especially in medical settings.

Ureter damage during a hysterectomy is generally considered preventable and raises a presumption of negligence, invoking the Res ipsa loquitur principle.

The burden of proof shifts to the surgeon to prove that the injury was not caused by negligence.

Other doctrines like Therapeutic misadventure or Medical maloccurrence address unavoidable complications or recognized risks, which do not fit this scenario.

questions.text: Invisible tattoos during autopsy can be detected by
questions.solution:
Invisible tattoos, though not visible on the skin, may result in the migration of tattoo pigments to the regional lymph nodes through lymphatic drainage. During an autopsy, examining the regional lymph nodes can reveal the presence of pigments that have migrated from the site of the tattoo.

This method is particularly useful in cases involving heavily decomposed bodies or tattoos made with non-traditional pigments that may not fluoresce under UV light.

Rule Out:

  • a) Ultraviolet rays: Detects fluorescent tattoos but not invisible tattoos with non-UV-reactive inks.
  • b) Infrared rays: Not applicable for tattoo detection.
  • d) Local skin biopsy: Can confirm the presence of pigments microscopically, but pigments may not remain in the skin due to migration, making lymph node examination more reliable.

Key Takeaways:

  1. Regional lymph node biopsy is a reliable method to detect tattoo pigments that have migrated, especially in invisible tattoos.
  2. Lymph node analysis is crucial in forensic identification, particularly for decomposed or altered bodies.
  3. This highlights the importance of systemic examination during autopsy.

questions.text: Identify
questions.solution:
Definition of Suggillation:

Suggilation refers to postmortem lividity or hypostasis, which is the pooling of blood in the dependent parts of the body after death due to gravity.

It appears as purplish-red discoloration on the skin and is often mistaken for bruising.

Mechanism of Formation:

After the heart stops pumping, blood settles in the lowest parts of the body.

This causes visible discoloration in areas that are not under pressure.

Key Features of Suggilation:

Begins 20-30 minutes after death and becomes fixed (non-blanching) after 8-12 hours.

The distribution of suggilation can help determine body position at the time of death.

Rule Out Explanation:

Option (a): Algor Mortis:

Algor mortis refers to the cooling of the body after death and does not involve visible discoloration of the skin.

Option (c): Putrefaction:

Putrefaction involves the decomposition of body tissues due to bacterial activity, often producing bloating, marbling, and a foul odor. It is a later stage of decomposition, not an immediate postmortem change like suggilation.

Option (d): Marbling:

Marbling is the greenish-black discoloration along veins due to decomposition and is seen in the later stages of putrefaction. It does not resemble the uniform, purplish-red patches of suggilation.

Key Takeaways:

Suggilation is a critical postmortem change used in forensic investigations to determine the time since death and the position of the body after death.

It differs from marbling, which is a putrefactive change, and from bruising, which occurs during life due to trauma.

Forensic distinctions between postmortem changes like suggilation, rigor mortis, and algor mortis are essential for accurate medicolegal evaluations.

The appearance and distribution of suggilation can provide clues about possible movement of the body postmortem.

questions.text: Ophitoxaemia is:
questions.solution:
Ophitoxaemia characterizes the clinical spectrum ofsnakebite envenomation.

Epidemiology:

Snakebite is more prevalent in rural than urban areas, commonly seen in summers, in males, farmers and mostly at night. Most of the bites are on lower extremities since the victims are bitten by treading on or near the snake.

History:

The time elapsed since the bite is important to determine if the process is confined locally or if systemic signs have developed. Obtain a description of the snake to determine its species.

Onset of symptoms and sudden progression are more common with elapidae bite rather than Viperidae. Most cobra, krait and sea snakebites would show symptoms within the first 6 hours, the shortest time is for the sea snakes. Early and intense pain implies significant envenomation.

Local signs and symptoms:

Fang marks, pain, bleeding, bruising, lymphangitis, lymph node enlargement, inflammation, blistering, local infection, abscess formation and necrosis.
